Posts.Content: Hello Maryon, I have had cellulitis in my arm (also after having all lymph nodes removed from that side). It was slightly swollen, red rash, and painful to touch.  I had two weeks of heavy duty antibiotics (two types) which cleared it. I hope you have seen an improvement in yours by now.
Posts.Title: gout

Posts.Content: Hi there,  i haven't seen George around tonight so I have answered the question. Thanks for highlighting it.
Posts.Title: dreamthief,somebody needs your help

Posts.Content: Hi, The @ function doesn't work on an I pad.
Posts.Title: How do I change my perspective of a death sentence?

Posts.Content: Hi Sheryl, it it seems unlikely it is anything significant but I would mention it to your oncologist when you see him next (if you see home before chemo sessions), or give your BCN a ring.
Posts.Title: breast lump

Posts.Content: This sounds like a fabulous idea.  I know there are organisations which arrange voluntary service trips overseas with plenty of different choices for things to do.
Posts.Title: A Fundraising Trip abroad After Treatment ?

Posts.Content: Good luck to both of you today. Remember three rules 1) keep calm, deep breath, you can do this 2) stay away from Google 3) come back and talk to us.
Posts.Title: One more day to go.

Posts.Content: Hi, bp at that level shouldn't make you feel dizzy as George says. it is possible the chemo is making you anaemic which would cause dizziness. I think that is unlikely though assuming you had a blood test before chemo last week as they would not have gone ahead if your red cells were too low. Also if you aren't eating much because you feel sick That can make you feel dizzy. either way if it doesn't improve I would definitely get it checked. Call your chemo unit for advice.
Posts.Title: 2 fec feeling dizzy

Posts.Content: Morning. Most doctors would use the term NED (no evidence of disease), rather than all clear. I would say that you were NED after your lumpectomy as the margins and lymph nodes were clear. Mentally at that point I found I could say I had Cancer.......rather than I have.......
Posts.Title: when is all clear?

Posts.Content: I've had 4 annual mammograms since my cancer now, and worry about each one. I try and keep busy and distract myself as much as possible. I don't think there is an easy answer though.
Posts.Title: Controlling Anxiety while waiting for results!

Posts.Content: I've had 4 annual mammograms since my cancer now, and worry about each one. I try and keep busy and distract myself as much as possible. I don't think there is an easy answer though.
Posts.Title: Controlling Anxiety while waiting for results!

Posts.Content: I would elevate them as often as possible.  Also very gentle stroking (hardly touching, no pressure) upwards from the foot to the knee might help a little.
Posts.Title: Letrozole, Zoladex and swollen feet

Posts.Content: Hi Caroline, well done for getting to this final appointment. i think if you haven't got any burning questions to ask that's fine. I would just make sure you know what the plan is for follow up so that you know when to expect appointments.
Posts.Title: Last appointment

Posts.Content: Hi JJ, I agree, 4 years after my treatment finished I still use aloe Vera gel for moisturising, any minor rashes, and after sun. Just one word of caution for everyone to check with your radio therapist if you are still having treatment as not all units allow its use during treatment.
Posts.Title: Aloe Vera gel

Posts.Content: Hi Shaz, I'm afraid I don't have any answers for you but I'm bumping this up to see if anyone else can help. You could also post a question to the nurses in our ask an expert section if you don't want to wait.
Posts.Title: Hard lumpy area in reconstructed breast

Posts.Content: Hi, I hope you are feeling a bit better today. It is very hard as we finish treatment. Somehow everyone expects us to be "over it", but it's not that simple. The side effects do linger for some time, we still feel tired, plus all the psychological effects and worries. I hope that you do manage to enjoy your Christmas, and that 2016 is a better year.
Posts.Title: The Miseries

Posts.Content: Hi, im sorry to hear of your diagnosis, which I think is very rare. if you want to talk this through with someone please feel free to call the helpline on 0808 808 0000. They are open from 9 am until 8 pm every weekday.
Posts.Title: Multiple Fibroadenomas

Posts.Content: Always Baking Hi Lakeslover,  Quick question, is there a simple way l can refresh my post l put up yesterday.  lt disappeared instantly down the  page .  l'm used to a quick 'share' on fb, so its easy to bring it to top of the page (cant do 'copy and paste..with my chemo head)  Thnx   Post was ''Just when ...    Thnx  The only way I know is to add a new reply to it. That then brings it to the top of the latest activity feed.
Posts.Title: Back Pain Post Radio?

Posts.Content: Hi, maybe be stupid but I'm with you on this one. I go into panic mode every year. hope there isn't too long to wait before the date, and the results.
Posts.Title: dreaded mammogram date

Posts.Content: Yes it seems like forever. This year they told me the results would take 4 weeks then I received a letter after 1 week. Well you can imagine what I thought........but it was clear. added pressure as my husband died in December, the mammo was the day after his funeral and I had to open the letter on my own. anyway I'm ok. Hard I know but try and push the date out of your mind for now. I find head in the sand and loads of distractions works for me.....white wine anyone??
Posts.Title: dreaded mammogram date

Posts.Content: Thanks George. comprehensive and very useful. I have saved it for the future.
Posts.Title: Aromatase Inhibitors - All Brands of The 4 Hormonal Therapy Table...

Posts.Content: Hi, with th such a recent CT scan I think it is unlikely to be serious progression. but of course you are doing the right thing by mentioning it to her oncologist.
Posts.Title: Lung pain.

Posts.Content: Hi Matthew, Sorry you haven't had any replies yet. I'm just bumping this up to see if anyone can help. The breast group is so busy things can often slide right down the page without being noticed. I did have back pain after my treatment. The doctors were sure it was muscular possibly related to being tense, and it went away after a while. That was 4 1/2 years ago.
Posts.Title: Back Pain Post Radio?

Posts.Content: Hello, i was in exactly this position in December 2011. Had WLE and full node clearance, just the sentinel node was positive. I was strongly er+. I was given the option of chemo or not. my oncologist went through the expected survival stats with and without chemo, for me the difference was very small...about 2% in 10 years. i decided not to have it, I had rads and I'm on tamoxifen. so far I am ok.  The only thing I would add is whatever you decide it is important you can do so with no regrets. I know I took a small chance. But if the Cancer comes back I will have no way of knowing whether or not it would have done so even if I had had the chemo. So if it does, I will just have to deal with it!
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy with W L E with one node positive

Posts.Content: Yes, I have also read that you should not drink red bush tea if you have hormone sensitive breast cancer.
Posts.Title: Red Bush Tea

Posts.Content: Hello Jackie, if if your arm is more enlarged and painful today I recommend you get someone to look at it in case you do have an infection. i have lymphodema in my arm and recently had an infection which needed heavy duty antibiotics to shift. It started with pain, the arm was painful to touch, a sort of sensitive stinging. Then I developed a rash over it.
Posts.Title: Lymnphedema

Posts.Content: Hi, As this is a busy group posts get lost down the list very easily. So I am just bumping this up to see if anyone can help you.  If you don't get any replies you could give the helpline a ring when they are open tomorrow and see what advice they can give you.
Posts.Title: Chemo effect on knee replacement

Posts.Content: Hi, The radiitherapy continues to work for two or three weeks after treatment is finished and you will continue to be tired for that time, and likely for a while afterwards. I had about 6 weeks off (from an office job) after my treatment finished and then went back to work on a phased return. I suggest before the meeting you phone the helpline here and get some advice on your rights. When you do feel ready to return (and your doctor agrees) it would be best to make sure HR are involved and the return to work plan is agreed in writing.
Posts.Title: Confused need some advice please

Posts.Content: Hi, You might find this recent thread on a similar topic helpful. community.macmillan.org.uk/.../864692
Posts.Title: Megastrol

Posts.Content: Well I'm no medical expert. But I wonder if during the shock all your muscles tensed up, like really bad cramp? That would leave you with the pains you describe. if you are worried about it give the helpline a call and see what they advise.
Posts.Title: Anaphylaxtic shock

Posts.Content: They will need to check the previous radiotherapy to see exactly where it was given and make sure the treatment areas do not overlap.
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy date changed

Posts.Content: Hi, i would ask if drinks are available on the chemo ward, most provide them but some don't. also if you are driving or being driven are there any concessions for the car park.
Posts.Title: Questions to ask.

Posts.Content: Hi, im afraid I can't help you, but I thought I would bump this up in case there is anyone in the Breast group who can help.
Posts.Title: Weekly taxol

Posts.Content: I think every unit is different. My first annual check results took 6 weeks to be sent. Generally I would agree, no news is good news. Where there is something to worry about the results are usually fast tracked. However given the looming Christmas break if you are worried I would give them a ring on Monday.
Posts.Title: mammogram results?

Posts.Content: Hi, i have have had a similar experience but the other way round. I was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2011. In 2013 my husband was diagnosed with lung cancer.  I had the lump excised, radiotherapy, and tamoxifen and at my last check up I was clear. I cared for my husband through chemo, radiotherapy, tumour spread, and finally until he died in December 2014. People on here have been a great support for me, I could not have come this far without their help.
Posts.Title: All about face!

Posts.Content: Great to read a positive story.
Posts.Title: Positive News

Posts.Content: Hi, It sounds as if your doctors are really on the ball. I have to ask each time for a copy of any letters or I don't get one. My husband was treated at a different hospital and frequently didn't get copies of letters even when he asked for them.
Posts.Title: Hospital letters

Posts.Content: Hi Carol, I don't want to sound negative but I have seen this question before, and I think flying could be a problem as your immune system will be low. Lots of people in a confined space, and lots of bugs so quite a risk. The same might also be true of a cruise ship. You would need to take advice from your oncologist on this. Also if you think of travelling without insurance especially on a cruise be aware of the costs of medical evacuation. I have seen figures of £10,000 quoted if you need to fly back with a medical escort, and I have no idea how much emergency evacuation from a ship would cost. Maybe you could plan a holiday away in the uk somewhere?
Posts.Title: Any advise re a mini cruise (GB)

Posts.Content: Sorry, I got confused by you mentioning flying back.  Travelling within gb should definitely be doable. We went away for a week to Snowdonia when my husband was having chemo, picking the week when we knew he would be feeling best. Our only issue was that his chemo was then delayed a week, so we ended up being away earlier in his cycle than we wanted. But still had a good time.
Posts.Title: Any advise re a mini cruise (GB)

Posts.Content: I also meant to say if you did think about coming up here the doctors surgery in Hawkshead (10 mins away) is fantastic, and geared up to see holiday visitors if you needed them.
Posts.Title: Any advise re a mini cruise (GB)

Posts.Content: The helpline are still open until 8pm tonight if you want to give them a quick ring.
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Now that is a coincidence. I used to live in Far Sawrey near hilltop, and still have an apartment there.
Posts.Title: Any advise re a mini cruise (GB)

Posts.Content: Hi, i wondered if it might be possible for your granddaughter to go to an after school club for the rest of this term? It would give you a few hours more breathing time each day, and she would probably enjoy it.
Posts.Title: Completely fed up

Posts.Content: Yes the tower bank food is lovely, and the food at the Cuckoo Brow in far sawrey now it's been done up (used to be the Sawrey hotel).  My son works in the cafe at Lakeland (in Windermere). He gets staff discount in the store so I'm often tempted into buying something I didn't really need.
Posts.Title: Any advise re a mini cruise (GB)

Posts.Content: Hi there, I was exactly the same. Abnormality on mammogram, no one could feel the lump. I had lumpectomy, lymph nod s removed and radiotherapy. My tumour was grade 2 and fairly small. It was also hormone positive so I'm on Tamoxifen. None of it is easy, but it is entirely doable.  In general lumps pick d up on routine mammogram have a slightly better prognosis, but what is more important is the grade and type of tumour. All this was 4 years ago. Up to now that have been clear, I'm just waiting for the results of my 4 year mammogram now.
Posts.Title: New diagnosis

Posts.Content: Hugs to you too Elaine. My grandchildren have kept me going many times over the last few years. Enjoy your Christmas.
Posts.Title: Christmas reflection

Posts.Content: Hello, Yes, of course you can ask. It's completely up to you whether you take any treatment or not.  I would go to your next appointment with your oncologist and explain why you are worried and ask what the options are.  If it would help you are also welcome to call the nurses on the helpline. The number is 0808 808 0000 and they are there weekdays from 9am until 8pm.
Posts.Title: Paclitaxel, Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: I was also treated in 2011 and have lymphodema in my breast and arm. The swelling in my Breast does go up and down, as you say sometimes a dent around the scar,mand sometimes a full breast. but if this is a new symptom for you I suggest you give your lymphodema nurse a call (assuming you have one).
Posts.Title: Wanting to put my mind at rest.

Posts.Content: Hi, you ou need to wait for your immune system to return to normal. One factor to take into account is whether you are also going to have radiotherapy? if not I would be tempted to leave it around 6 weeks, and ideally get your GP to do a blood test first to make sure your system is sufficient recovered. that may be a bit cautious, but better safe than sorry as they say. best thing to do is to ask your oncologist.
Posts.Title: How Soon?

Posts.Content: I was in a similar position and went to my GP who found I was very anaemic. Apparently it is common after radiitherapy, and in my case because I was on tamoxifen giving me heavy periods my blood didn't have time to recover.  Iron tablets, and it's all sorted now.
Posts.Title: 8 Months post radiotherapy still shattered

Posts.Content: I was offered the choice (grade 2, 2cm tumour, 1 lymph node affected). Strongly hormone positive. i asked my oncologist what difference it would make and he went through the 10 year survival stats with and without it. As there was only about a 1% difference I decided it wasn't worth going through the problems of treatment and side effects. I am taking tamoxifen which gave a very big improvement.  I am three years down the line with no problems so far. the important thing whichever you decide is to have no regrets. Try asking yourself how you will feel if you turn down chemo and the disease comes back. can you say well it might have done so anyway, and not have regrets? Or would you feel that you should have done everything possible and had the chemo?
Posts.Title: has any one been offered the choice of chemo

Posts.Content: Hi, obviously  it is right to get this change checked by your oncologist. But I also had a change in appearance of my nipple for a while after rads. It was just another side effect and went back to normal fairly quickly (within a month or so).
Posts.Title: Surgey and Radiotherapy completed what next???

Posts.Content: Congratulations, great news. For travel insurance try Eurotunnel. As long as you are stable, not terminal and not travelling against medical advice they will give you annual European cover on their normal rate. You don't have to be going through the tunnel. There are also other recommendations on the travel insurance blog.
Posts.Title: I think I am a NEDdy

Posts.Content: Hi fiddlesticks, My tumour was close to the nipple too. Although it got darker during the radiitherapy and a little scaley it soon returned to normal. Now 4 years later it is no different to the other one. My WLE scar has faded, and there is only a dent which shows I had the op, but it only shows when I don't have any clothes on.
Posts.Title: Nipple & radiotherapy

Posts.Content: As well as an emergency clothes kit for any emergency hospital admissions include a spare phone, I pad and kindle charger. Plus leave a purse in there with £10 so you have some cash with you to buy stuff from the trolley when you start to feel better. cant remember if it is already on the list, but orange and pineapple squash for those days you don't feel like tea or coffee.  Starburst sweets ets are good for odd tasting or dry mouth.
Posts.Title: Chemo Survival Kit – Version 3 – 8 April 2015 - please read and contribute...

Posts.Content: George, i think you have proved something I have long suspected, not only is there chemo brain, there is also carers brain, or maybe chemo brain is infectious?? my husband and I would often have conversations going something like "where did I put the wotsit" "it's in the cupboard behind the thingy"   etc  the he trouble is we both knew what we meant!
Posts.Title: Chemo Brain - Er' Now Where Was I :-)

Posts.Content: You might find these two blogs helpful as well. community.macmillan.org.uk/.../what-should-i-bring-to-my-chemo-part-one community.macmillan.org.uk/.../what-should-i-bring-to-my-chemo-part-two
Posts.Title: start of chemo

Posts.Content: Hi, Your post made me think for a while. I have had breast cancer, and also been widowed. Of the two the cancer was easier for me.....so far. But if I'm honest I would rather not have had to cope with either.
Posts.Title: Just thinking

Posts.Content: It's always disappointing when appointments don't go the way we expect or want. Do you have questions that this group could answer?
Posts.Title: start of chemo

Posts.Content: I would add a spare phone charger (in case you are there longer than planned), and some sweets to suck to get rid of any chemo taste.....sherbet limes or lemons, or starbursts work well. We took satsuma so for the same reason.  For me I would have to include my I pad too.....games, books, e mail to keep me amused.
Posts.Title: start of chemo

Posts.Content: Hello, I think many of us find it hard to get back to normal energy levels after treatment stops. I did, but eventually my doctor found I was severely anaemic which can be a result from radiotherapy. I am assuming your GP will have checked for this already. It's good that he is taking it seriously, I hope the egg turns out to be normal. If so maybe the answer is to keep building up the exercise slowly, hopefully it will get better.
Posts.Title: Frustrated lack of energy

Posts.Content: Hello silk painter, I'm just bumping this up to see if anyone can help you as posts quickly get lost in such a busy group. Good luck with your decision,
Posts.Title: Scarring

Posts.Content: Hi Mandy, I think you are talking about manual lymphatic drainage? It isn't so much rubbing, more very gentle light stroking. If you use too much pressure the lymphatic system closes and it doesn't work. It should always be done up the arm towards the shoulder. The best thing would be to ask your GP to refer you to a lymphodema specialist if you think you have a problem.
Posts.Title: Swelling in arm

Posts.Content: Hi, this is sounds like lymphodema in the Breast area to me. Give your BCN a ring and see if you can go and see her. Mine was able to show me how to manually drain it.
Posts.Title: Swollen arm/breast is it normal?

Posts.Content: Hi, I'm sure we all worry when we have these checks, it brings all those horrid feelings back. I know I do and I've just had my forth annual check up (which was clear). It's good that you have someone to go with you. Good luck.
Posts.Title: one year review tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hi, i have been on tamoxifen for just over three years now with few problems. a few hot flushes in the early days, an occasional one at night now. Nothing major. i find it harder to lose weight, but I haven't put any on. I think that people who have finished other treatments and have no problems on tamoxifen are often just out there getting on with life. It is the people who are having problems who are more likely to post asking for advice.
Posts.Title: Good news!!

Posts.Content: Hi there, I can see you have had a response from MistyMoley to you other post. Hopefully you will hear more soon, but I just wanted to add that if you are still worried you are welcome to call the helpline. They are open from 9am to 8pm every weekday.
Posts.Title: Why are they Re testing my Onco type dx with another sample ?

Posts.Content: Not all nurses are Cancer specialists. but it is a great pity that she didn't know how to find this forum, and needed you to give her the address.
Posts.Title: If a nurse doesn't even know.... !!

Posts.Content: Hello sniffy, Sorry you didn't get any replies to this earlier. I hope your problem has eased now and you were able to get to your scan.
Posts.Title: 2 down 4 to go - really bad diarrheoe today

Posts.Content: Hi, Just because your current certificate says you should be fit for work three weeks after rads finish doesn't mean that you can't get another one if you reach that point and are still too tired to return. Before doing anything else I would give the helpline here a ring and get some advice from them. Your employer has to make reasonable adjustments to support you in returning to work as you are now classed as having a disability. If your employer has an occupational health team I would also ask for a referral to them before you return to agree an appropriate schedule. Definitely phasing in the return, and taking into account the travelling time.
Posts.Title: Help ......

Posts.Content: Hi Dendy, i have lymphodema as well. Happy to answer any questions you have.
Posts.Title: Lymph node removal and under arm nerve

Posts.Content: Hi Val, Different hospitals do this in different ways. due to moving around I have been seen at three different hospitals over the last 5 years. At one it was all done on the same day and I was given the mammogram results then. At the other two they were separate days and I had to wait for results in the post (5 weeks later).  If you post the name of your hospital someone might have specific information for that clinic.
Posts.Title: Onco app & mammogram

Posts.Content: Hi, it it feels good to get and and do something which isn't hospital related doesn't it. Even if you end up feeling shattered. hope you are having a nice long lie in this morning.
Posts.Title: It seemed like a good idea at the time!!

Posts.Content: Hi, i have been been on it 3 1/2 years now. Initially I took it in the morning. But I found I felt queasy and had no appetite for a few hours afterwards. So I switched to taking it after my evening meal reasoning that I would then sleep the problems off! the only side effect I have now is the occasional hot flush at night. I have had all the different brands over the years, it doesn't seem to matter to me.
Posts.Title: Taking Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Here is a link to the macmillan recipe page. i hope you find it useful.
Posts.Title: Marker clip and chemo?

Posts.Content: rily, if if it helps when my Breast cancer was found the surgeon gave me the choice of removing it immediately or waiting a month until after Christmas. He said there was no additional risk involved in waiting that long.
Posts.Title: Daughter

Posts.Content: Hi, whether or not you are entitled to sick pay from your employer depends on what your contract says. So the first thing to do is to take a look at it.  You may be entitled to SSP if you earn more than £112 a week. if you have a look at your contract and see what it says the best thing then would be to give the helpline here a ring on Monday and they can talk you through anything you are entitled to. The number is 0808 808 0000.
Posts.Title: I need some advice please?

Posts.Content: Hi, I'm on tamoxifen which doesn't seem to have he same effect, but I know lots of ladies in this group will be taking a anastrazole. Hopefully by bumping this post up someone may see it who can give a more useful reply. My only suggestion would be to make sure you are using a moisturiser (with sun protection) and drinking plenty of water. But I suspect you are doing that so doubt if it's very helpful.  Dream thief if he is around may know if any of the other AIs might have less of an effect.
Posts.Title: Skin looks very dry on face

Posts.Content: Hi, I think the idea of cotton is to allow it to breathe, and keep the breast cooler rather than because of irritation. I used a halter heck soft bikini top to go to and from hospital as it was comfortable and quick to get on and off. Apart from that I went bra less wherever possible to keep the area cool.
Posts.Title: Bra for radiotherapy

Posts.Content: It is so hard when treatment finishes and we just want to put it all behind us.....but can't. The bone pain could well be from tamoxifen. Have you experimented with different brands? Some people find it does make a difference.  Also I found I had constant nausea when I started on tam, taking it in the morning. I switched to taking it after dinner in the evening and have had no problems since.
Posts.Title: when does this end.....

Posts.Content: Good luck. I have always found the technicians to be very sensitive once they know I had cancer. Hope you don't have too long to wait for the results.
Posts.Title: First mammogram

Posts.Content: I agree, very tru
Posts.Title: So true x

Posts.Content: Just put a fruit cake in the oven.......so that will be my treat today (eating it, not making it!).
Posts.Title: seize the day

Posts.Content: As you say you know the answer!!!! It's probably nothing, but you need to get it checked out. You could ring your BCN and see if she would take  a look.
Posts.Title: I know what the answer is but.....

Posts.Content: Well done for reaching the end. I think you have hit the nail on the head. There is life before BC, and life afterwards. It definitely made me reevaluate my life, which led to me giving up work and moving 300 miles to the Lake District.
Posts.Title: Who am I now? Answers on a postcard please.....

Posts.Content: Hi, these are are difficult days as you absorb everything you are being told. Try and focus right now on the fact that your lymph nodes are clear which is very good news. there is an April chemo thread here where people due to start chemo in April are sharing and comparing and it might help you to join that one. there is also information here from macmillan on triple negative Breast cancer.
Posts.Title: Triple negative ductal carcinoma

Posts.Content: I've heard this before, although personally I don't think I'd want to stuff cabbage down my bra!
Posts.Title: Anyone for Cabbage (Radiation related)

Posts.Content: If you are on Tam you don't need one as Tam actually strengthens the bones (and is good for the teeth).
Posts.Title: Quick question.

Posts.Content: Interesting, the ets of the range is already available on line.  Given er that this is a campaign for breast cancer I would have expected the post surgery bra to be launched at the same time as the others.
Posts.Title: M&S SHOWYOURBRASTRAP campaign

Posts.Content: You got too much time on your hands today George?
Posts.Title: Anyone for Cabbage (Radiation related)

Posts.Content: Well done him.
Posts.Title: Charity fundraiser

Posts.Content: Hello Helen, Feel free to ramble away!  You are making perfect sense to me. Waiting for results us a horrid scary time, I think I had myself convinced I would be terminal and had planned my funeral.......here I am currently Clear, after 4 years. I can't take the worry away, all I can say is to try and live one day at a time. Don't look forward. Get out in the fresh air fir a short walk if you can, or even sit in the garden. It's surprising how it helps. Good luck.
Posts.Title: bit of a ramble starting to wobble!

Posts.Content: Hi, I had a WLE and found the best thing in the weeks immediately after surgery were vests with inbuilt support which I bought at M &S. I also had a genie bra which was soft and worked well.
Posts.Title: bra's to wear after surgery

Posts.Content: Hi, One thing you could try is to monitor the brand of tam you are taking. Some people find different brands give them fewer side effects. To find out whether it is safe to take cod liver oil you could ask one of the nurses in our ask an expert section here. If you haven't had one recently I would ask your GP about a blood test to check for anaemia. 18 months after my treatment I was still very tired and my GP found I was very anaemic, a result of the treatment she thought.
Posts.Title: tamoxifen and cod liver oil

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah, My children were older when I was diagnosed. But you might find this Macmillan information about talking to children about cancer helpful if you haven't already seen it. www.macmillan.org.uk/.../talking-to-children
Posts.Title: Stage 3 breast cancer help & how to tell my children

Posts.Content: Hi Mike, There are a couple of tumour markers which can check for a recurrence of breast cancer. I think the same markers would be used in male and female Breast cancer. They are not often used in the UK, I think that's most likely because in women other tests are more accurate.  Lynda
Posts.Title: I had a clear blood test for Tumour Markers
